posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: Did anyone try connecting the adafruit 5mm LEDs beam brake sensors to the falcon 500 limit switch port?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
While I’ve never tried a Falcon500 with a beam break, looking through the documentation, it appears like it should be possible, though it may require some creative wiring.

Assuming the limit switch port on a Falcon500 works anything like the DIO port on the RoboRIO, then what we would typically do is supply the sensor with it’s own power from a VRM (the RIO doesn’t supply enough voltage for the line breaks we use), and connect only the signal output wire into the DIO.

The Falcon500 provides 3.3v on the limit switch port which may be enough to power the Adafruit sensor (and the Falcon500s documentation [pg40] states that an external pull-up resistor should not be needed), albeit at somewhat reduced range. Though you’ll likely need to connect it to a separate ground since you only have the two pins on the falcon itself.

Hard to tell without either device in front of me, I would think it would work but it may require some experimentation to get the wiring right.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
For something like this , I would connect the emitter (the part with two wires) to the RIO – this part just lights up (in the infrared) and you can get 5V at enough current from the RIO.  I would not recommend running ground wires between different parts of the robot, especially with a motor controller – Ground loop (electricity) - Wikipedia .

This leaves the detector.  The datasheet is in Chinese, but this clearly requires power and ground, and provides an output.  The Falcon 500 limit switch has ground and an input, but does not provide power.

The lack of power is a problem.  The easiest good solution is probably to use something called a “reed relay”.  Part # R56S−5D.5−6D would be a good choice.

With this part, you would wire pin 7 or 8 and either pin 1 or 14 to the Falcon 500 limit switch port.  Then, you would create a small circuit using pins 2 and 6, the three wires from the detector, and +5V and GND from the RIO.  The relay isolates the Falcon 500 from the RIO, and the Falcon 500 side doesn’t need power – it’s just connected to a magnetically activated switch, and a switch is what the Falcon 500 is set up to use.

The relay needs ~25mA @5V .  The detector is rated for 100mA “ sink ”, so that works.

You want to connect +5V from the RIO to pin 2 of the relay and to the red wire from the detector.  Connect GND from the RIO to the black wire from the detector.  And, connect pin 6 of the relay to the remaining (white or yellow) wire from the detector.  Since the emitter is also getting power from the RIO, the red and black wires from the emitter go to +5V and GND from the RIO, respectively.

A small breadboard PCB would make it pretty easy to put something like this together.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: The Adafruit page indicates it’s an NPN output (sinks to ground), so you should just be able to power the sensor via 3.3 or 5v externally, then connect the sensor output to the Talon’s input pin. The input pin is pulled to 3.3v internally, and the sensor will pull it low when triggered.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Yes, something like this will probably work.  I’d still opt for the isolation though.

There is a already connection between ground everywhere of course, but if the motor controller is drawing a lot of current, the IR drop could be enough to be an issue, particularly with 3v3 signals (and maybe also not great wiring).

And, tying the grounds together through some signal-sized wiring (which is what often happens in this type of setup) can end badly, if the main negative wire to the motor controller comes loose, etc.  That’s on top of the general ground loop thing.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
Fair warning:  The sensor is very susceptible to IR light (or maybe it’s UV light – I don’t remember.)    At bare minimum, I’d want to put some sort of de-bounce circuit on it before using it as a limit switch input.  (Possible that the Falcon has that built in?? )    We switched to using a proximity switch ( see link below) that also had the advantage of not needing both an emitter and a detector.

Electrical Characteristics: U: 5VDC I: 100mA Sn: 3-80CM Size: Diameter: 17MM Sensor length: 45MM Lead length: 45CM  Applications: 1. Production line automatic counting equipment 2. multi-function reminder 3. go maze robot 4. kitchen automation system...

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Just to make the point about isolation a bit more concrete, I’ve seen both of these scenarios (as a CSA ):

The heavy-gauge (>= 12 AWG) ground wire for a motor controller comes loose (perhaps intermittently) and 60A or so flows through the light-gauge (>= 28 AWG) “signal” ground wire, circuit traces in the RIO and motor controller meant for low current, etc. – with no fuse/breaker in this path (guess how this ends – it’s pretty obvious when this happens).

The heavy-gauge (>= 12 AWG) ground wire for a motor controller comes loose (perhaps intermittently) and 60A or so flows through the light-gauge (>= 28 AWG) “signal” ground wire, circuit traces in the RIO and motor controller meant for low current, etc. – with no fuse/breaker in this path (guess how this ends – it’s pretty obvious when this happens).

Generic logic levels for 3.3V inputs is low is <= 0.8V and high is >=2.0V, so there is only 1.2V between these, with everything referenced to ground.  If the motor is drawing 60A, Ohm’s law says (E=IR) that for every milli-Ohm (0.001 Ω), the voltage drop is 0.06V.  12 AWG normally has a resistance in the range of 1.5+ milli-Ohms per ft.  So, the voltage drop is ~0.1V per ft.  Add in traces in the PDH /PH, connectors, etc. and the noise margins start to get very slim.  If things don’t work reliably, it’s less obvious than in the first scenario, but I’m confident I’ve seen this problem also.

Generic logic levels for 3.3V inputs is low is <= 0.8V and high is >=2.0V, so there is only 1.2V between these, with everything referenced to ground.  If the motor is drawing 60A, Ohm’s law says (E=IR) that for every milli-Ohm (0.001 Ω), the voltage drop is 0.06V.  12 AWG normally has a resistance in the range of 1.5+ milli-Ohms per ft.  So, the voltage drop is ~0.1V per ft.  Add in traces in the PDH /PH, connectors, etc. and the noise margins start to get very slim.  If things don’t work reliably, it’s less obvious than in the first scenario, but I’m confident I’ve seen this problem also.

In my personal opinion, there should be a rule against ground loops.  There isn’t, but I pretty much always advise against anything that introduces one.  I’m sure it’s common to do things in ways that introduce them, and that things usually work.  But, if they don’t, smoked wires or flakey behavior are both non-negligible risks.

[Yes, I know 60A is high.  But it’s not outside the normal range, and the same issues can happen at somewhat lower currents.]

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked: I’m thinking about attempting to use the Hiletgo above direct into a Falcon as a limit switch - is that what you did, or did you connect the Hiletgo to the Roborio?

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked:
When using the air fruit IR beam brake sensors they need +5v to operate reliably although they will work at 3.3v. The Falcon Five hundred limit switch has an internal pull up resistor to 3.3v and the Roborio DIO pins have a pull up resistor to +5v. This difference in voltage is substantial enough to make it not desirable to tie both the DIO pin and the limit switch pin to the IR beam brake sensor (WHT). You should be able to simply place a diode with the anode facing the limit switch pin on the Falcon and tie the other end (cathode) to the DIO pin and the signal pin from the IR sensor. The diode will limit any backflow of current from the Roborio into the limit switch input on the Falcon. Something like this. image 984×524 5.03 KB

image 984×524 5.03 KB

image 984×524 5.03 KB

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked: Update - both Hiletgo and a Banner sensor connected directly to a Falcon 500 digital port work perfectly as a forward or reverse limit switch.  Of course the IR sensors need to get 5 or 12V from someplace - I’m using a VRM because I had one available
